1.00.text: G'day viewers, my name is Graeme Stevenson

3.32.text: and I'd like to invite you to come on a journey of

5.37.text:
creativity and learning and adventure
through the series Colour In Your Life.

9.78.text:
There's an artist in every family
throughout the world,

12.60.text:
and lots of times there's an artist
deep down inside all of us as well.

16.64.text: So grab your kids, your brothers, your sisters,

19.45.text: your aunties, uncles and mums and dads,

21.80.text:
and come and see how some of the best artists
in Australia do what they do.

63.59.text:
GRAEME : Well g'day viewers welcome back
at Colour In Your Life again.

66.43.text:
We're actually down in
country Victoria at the moment

69.99.text:
in a lovely area or little town called Benalla,
we're just outside on a property,

75.17.text:
and that property belongs to an incredibly
talented wildlife artist, Kate Ferguson.

80.33.text:
KATE : Nice to meet you, Graeme.
GRAME : Welcome to the show. Thank you so much.

82.85.text:
This is an amazingly beautiful area, I mean
Kate even your studio is just fantastic.

88.14.text:
But you really have a history that's greatly
involved with wildlife since you were a child.

93.22.text:
KATE : Yes.
GRAEME : And born in Africa…

95.63.text:
KATE : Yes.
GRAEME :  Moved to Australia at an early age

97.35.text: and obviously being part of that African scene,

100.77.text:
and a lot of your work is
based on the African animals.

103.17.text:
We have a real great common synergy
because I spent

105.80.text: quite a lot of time over there as you did too.

108.13.text: But the magnificence of the animals over there

110.29.text: and the way you portray them…

112.20.text:
Tell me a little bit about your history from
coming from there to where you are here.

116.74.text: KATE : My early childhood was fantastic in Africa.

119.84.text:
I spent a lot of time out
in the bush with my parents

124.00.text:
and we saw many amazing things,
and I just had a love of animals

128.67.text:
and a love of drawing so
it’s been a wonderful journey

134.09.text: and I actually call it a bit of safari

136.57.text:
to combine the two passions of
animals and art.

141.47.text:
We did move because of
political reasons out to Australia…

146.95.text: been a wonderful move for me.

149.32.text: And yes now I've settled into art full time.

153.51.text:
GRAEME : Your history since you've been here,
you're really dedicated,

156.49.text:
I mean you sort of tend to notice artists that
are incredibly dedicated to what they do,

161.35.text:
but you're involved in a number
of wildlife art organizations as well?

165.35.text:
KATE : Yes.
GRAEME : And I think sort of part of your

168.16.text:
doctrine is helping preservation
of a number of the animals

173.33.text:
and using, or Kate uses her work
to be able to facilitate doing that.

177.36.text:
What are some of the organizations
that you're involved with these days?

179.80.text:
KATE : My main one is Artists for Conservation
and that's based in Canada.

185.75.text:
A lot of it's online, which is fantastic.
They run a really fabulous website

190.27.text: that's very state of the art.

192.27.text: As a member you have a little profile

195.89.text:
and proceeds of your art goes back
into conservation and it's of your choice.

200.76.text:
GRAEME : Which is fantastic.
KATE : It is a fantastic organization.

204.26.text:
GRAEME : You've won numerous awards as well
with what you do, which is great.

207.91.text:
It's obviously the accolades
of the people out there

209.80.text: that appreciate what you're doing for a start.

212.25.text:
But even before we started the show today
and talking to you

216.66.text:
about the sort of common synergy
we have with nature…

219.37.text:
KATE : Yes.
GRAEME : …and what these animals

220.75.text:
represent to us and it really is just,
it's amazing to see them out in the wild.

224.46.text:
You can't really do it justice until
you’re there and we're lucky enough

227.23.text:
to have been able to have done that,
which is just amazing.

230.38.text:
But today one of the other
iconic animals of Africa

233.82.text:
is the lion and unfortunately
the lion is quite endangered…

236.88.text:
KATE : It is, yes.
GRAEME : …these days as well.

238.10.text:
I mean their numbers have declined
quite rapidly in certain areas,

241.79.text:
but Kate is going to be doing a pencil drawing.
But you do all the other mediums as well?

246.40.text:
I mean you can see by the picture behind us,
which is magnificent,

250.40.text:
you're very efficient with oils and acrylics
and the other mediums as well.

257.27.text: If you want to get in touch with Kate

259.57.text: for being able to do what she does,

261.43.text:
and particularly in this
magnificent area she lives in,

263.98.text:
I would suggest you get
in touch with her as well.

266.69.text:
But we're going to do
a pencil drawing today…

270.18.text:
KATE : That's right.
GRAEME : And we’ll start with that

273.21.text:
and follow through and obviously
you'll see a lot of these images created

277.21.text:
that Kate's done and it really is
a magnificent journey of a woman

280.60.text: that's had a pretty incredible life I think.

282.93.text: So let’s go and start on it.

300.59.text: GRAEME : Okay well before we even start

304.69.text:
I mean generally artists will use
a towel or a piece of clothe…

308.04.text:
KATE : Yes.
GRAEME : But this is a really cool invention.

310.85.text:
You've actually set yourself up
with a little board…

313.27.text:
KATE : I have.
GRAEME : With padding on the back,

314.80.text:
like felt padding, which just rests
on this little section here,

319.08.text: and you just simply slide it along.

324.12.text:
And obviously that stops Kate
from smudging her work.

327.53.text:
And I think, when you look at Kate's work,
it's got this wonderful soft subtleness in it.

333.89.text:
You'll find a lot of artists,
they'll be fairly heavy

336.77.text: but yours is really smooth and subtle all the way.

339.72.text:
Show us the techniques.
I know you've got some STAEDTLER pencils there.

343.40.text:
KATE : Yes.
GRAEME : What type of paper are we using here?

345.39.text:
KATE : This is the Archers watercolour paper.
GRAEME : Okay.

348.50.text:
KATE : It's hot pressed and 300 GSM.
GRAEME : Okay.

351.58.text: KATE : So it's a nice solid…

355.33.text: a smooth finish with a slight tooth, which I like.

359.14.text: I actually draw the outline with a HB.

361.54.text:
GRAEME : Yeah?
KATE : Which is very light.

364.15.text:
And I pretty much do the whole drawing
with just 2B and a 3B pencil.

370.89.text:
I really like the STAEDTLER
with this combination of paper.

374.96.text:
GRAEME : Yeah.
KATE : They're a very consistent pencil.

377.69.text:
GRAEME : Okay.
KATE : And quite a hard lead

379.70.text:
and very rarely get the little
gritty bits

385.48.text:
which can damage the surface of the paper.
GRAEME : You get a dead zone in the pencil.

389.94.text: KATE : So I will start with her eyes.

394.25.text:
GRAEME : If you’re looking at really
capturing the detail of an animal,

398.08.text: if you’re an expressionist or an abstract artist,

401.14.text: a lot of that comes from the heart.

403.22.text:
But when you're a realist artist, what Kate's
done is obviously set up her Mac over there,

409.16.text: and then these are her own photos,

411.55.text:
when you were back last year
in Africa weren’t you?

414.51.text: GRAEME : And obviously she can refer to those,

417.19.text:
and it's really important to
obviously have good material,

420.25.text:
particularly if it's your own of course,
to be able to work from.

425.19.text:
this is...
Some artists would trace,

430.92.text: you’re good enough to just draw.

432.22.text: KATE : I've drawn all my life.

434.11.text:
GRAEME : Isn't that great?
KATE : So it has been great.

437.52.text:
GRAEME : Yeah there are not
a lot of artists that can do that.

439.51.text:
You've got to be very specialized
and I think extremely talented

443.33.text:
to know just exactly
where everything’s got to go.

445.48.text:
Generally a lot of us stumble
around the pencil going ‘that's not right’.

449.63.text: Okay, now the rubber that you've got there?

451.85.text: KATE : Yes I use a knead-able rubber.

454.17.text: And the secondary one is a vinyl rubber,

459.77.text:
Certain brands of knead-able erasers
are better than others.

462.80.text:
GRAEME : A lot of artists will...
obviously you being right handed,

465.58.text:
will do the sketch and
start going from left to right?

468.87.text:
KATE : Yes.
GRAEME : But you're building

470.94.text:
the essence of the picture up,
very soft layers at a time…

474.11.text:
KATE : Yes, that's right.
GRAEME : …to get it where you need to go.

475.95.text: KATE : And with this I can move across it.

478.43.text:
GRAEME : You don't find that the edge of that
interferes?

480.81.text:
I mean the beauty about drawing is
using the natural arch of your hand…

485.37.text:
KATE : Yes.
GRAEME : …to be able to create circles and form.

487.79.text: You don't find that gets in the way of doing that?

490.21.text:
KATE : I found it a little bit awkward when
I started but it's something you get used to.

494.00.text: So yeah you can actually just sort of rest

496.64.text: and get a bit of a…

498.41.text: because some of the work is quite…

501.68.text:
you need quite a bit of movement in it. So yeah,
fine, but it does take a few days to get use to.

506.73.text:
GRAEME : Sure, sure.
KATE : It's great. Keep the work,

509.86.text: all the oils and dirt off your hands.

512.84.text:
And I always start with clean hands,
keeps it off the paper.

516.35.text: GRAEME : I think part of the mystique

517.99.text:
and the intrigue of great animal pictures is
what you're doing right now,

521.65.text:
which is the eyes.
KATE : Yes.

523.42.text:
GRAEME : And if you capture
the essence of the eyes of an animal…

526.06.text:
KATE : Yes.
GRAEME : …you tend to capture their soul as well.

529.56.text: GRAEME : Your favorite essence about animals

532.13.text:
is the larger animals.
KATE : Yes.

534.44.text:
GRAEME : Obviously the predators,
and you've got the bison

537.59.text: and I've seen that you've done for…

539.09.text:
and you've been, we've both been
in the same place as well Jackson Hole.

542.57.text:
KATE : That's right.
GRAEME : The galleries in Jackson Hole…

545.65.text: I was in the Trail Side Gallery many years ago.

547.92.text: And you are actually in the Wildlife Museum?

550.59.text:
KATE : I have, yes, I have been
in the Wildlife Museum show

556.15.text: GRAEME : That's wonderful. And I notice that,

557.94.text:
obviously with the beautiful picture
that you've got there,

561.03.text:
there's a continual referral…
KATE : Yes.

565.28.text:
Notice when people start or
they're beginning art is that they...

570.80.text: He gets a vision of his dad in his head,

573.18.text:
and he draws a circle,
some curly hair and some eyes.

576.25.text: And to that child, that's his dad.

578.85.text: And we sort of tend to take that on ourselves

580.79.text:
into our adulthood and it's really
the interpretation

587.86.text:
And you interpret it quite exactly.
KATE : I do, yes.

590.90.text:
GRAEME : Where as other people
would just willy-nilly,

593.40.text:
you know an elephant has triangle ears
so they draw a triangle.

597.46.text:
GRAEME : Without thinking of what the rest
of the structure of it’s like.

600.08.text: KATE : Nature has composed things so perfectly

603.19.text: that I don't want to change it or abstract it.

608.50.text:
So I just, I like to put my own artistic
expression

611.60.text: to the animal but keep it as it’s designed.

618.11.text:
GRAEME : Yeah.
KATE : I really keep going until I get it right

620.93.text: and that's just, a challenge to me as well,

625.89.text: So I just keep going until I get it right.

629.81.text: And I do have other people look at the work and

632.18.text:
check it over for me as well…
GRAEME : Sure.

637.24.text:
GRAEME : Do you use a mirror?  I can remember…
KATE : I do.

641.64.text:
GRAEME : …with Robert, even Raymond…
KATE : Yes.

643.91.text: GRAEME : …they would look at it through a mirror.

645.34.text:
Which obviously gives you
the other side of your brain

647.77.text:
looking at it as well.
KATE : That's right.

649.18.text: Yeah it's very, very important to reverse it.

652.50.text: Especially if the eyes are not,

655.36.text: you know, correct and they need a bit of work.

658.39.text: It straight away points it out for me.

662.39.text: GRAEME : Doing wildlife as your art career,

664.71.text:
you really get the chance
to smell the dew on the grass

668.67.text:
when you’re out on safari.
KATE : Yes.

670.92.text:
KATE : That's right.
GRAEME : That's one of the great parts about it.

674.24.text: I can only speak for myself of course,

675.94.text: but that comes back into your mind.

678.45.text:
KATE : Oh it does.
GRAEME : You can hear everything can't you?

680.50.text:
It's like you’re there again.
KATE : That's right.

682.14.text:
And I think that's the
essential part of my artwork

684.88.text: and why I use my own reference photos,

687.81.text: because I've experienced the whole thing

690.65.text: that transfers then into the piece of art.

694.23.text:
So it's, yes, all those sights and sounds,
everything comes back.

700.68.text:
GRAEME : Drift away, drift away.
KATE : Oh yes.

703.90.text:
GRAEME : What I might do, because this is a
fairly complex drawing that Kate's doing,

708.60.text:
is we're going to let her
work on this for a while,

710.97.text: and come back shortly and see how she's going.

729.12.text:
GRAEME : Well I can see that,
as Kate progresses through this,

733.85.text: is that you've swapped to a 3B pencil.

736.61.text: And a lot of people might not be aware

739.37.text: that there are a number of different B pencils

743.21.text: that are graded to harder leads to quite soft.

747.72.text: And you've got a 3B at the moment.

750.36.text:
Do you use any other leads
that are heavier than 3B?

753.98.text: KATE : With this combination of pencils and paper

757.31.text:
I don't usually, so I find I can get
very dark with the 3B.

764.64.text:
And I like to do, as you can see
building it up here,

771.34.text:
And even though it looks flat at the moment,
it also gives it a softness.

775.92.text: So that where the shadows meeting the light areas,

781.17.text:
when I come in with the 3B,
its a little bit different with the mouth,

785.82.text:
but there's a rolling sensation rather than
the 3B coming in and meeting a hard edge.

792.68.text:
So I'll get a nice softness
by having that 2B underneath.

798.49.text: it really does take a great deal…

800.17.text:
KATE : It does.
GRAEME : …of effort to get it where it needs to go.

802.08.text:
But I think that's
the beauty of what it is as well.

804.46.text:
I mean even looking at the pictures
of the elephants walking at the moment,

809.06.text: you can see that you've gradiated out that dust

811.31.text: and that perspective in the background.

812.74.text:
KATE : Yes.
GRAEME : So you can see

814.89.text:
the tonal effects all the way through it,
which I think is wonderful.

817.43.text:
KATE : Yes, that was an interesting piece
to be able to do,

820.20.text:
and working with the pencil
by using the pencil to its full capacity…

825.37.text:
GRAEME : Yeah.
KATE : …to get that bit of perspective with…

829.91.text:
GRAEME : Really, really well done.
KATE : It's still not finished

831.38.text:
and I would say I'm probably
sixty hours into it already.

834.84.text:
GRAEME : Wow.
KATE : Still quite a way to go.

836.63.text:
Some progress faster than others,
but it is a slow process.

842.45.text:
GRAEME : But I think it's amazing
that you can see what you can do.

845.36.text: You know you hold up these pencils…

848.80.text:
a hundred hours later you've got
this magnificent drawing in front of you,

854.22.text:
KATE : I think that's one of the
fascinating things about pencil and

858.68.text: and what I most enjoy about it is

860.69.text:
they're the sort of most simple
and fundamental tools

863.78.text: that you can use for artwork.

869.20.text:
and white paper and it's just then a bit of
choice and experience into what you produce,

880.61.text:
Yes there's a bit rolled into it
but it's a challenge as well…

884.21.text:
GRAEME : Yeah.
KATE : …to get from an outline,

886.49.text: and when I say, when I'm teaching,

888.08.text: I say it's actually an outline that you shade in.

891.77.text: But it's your choice and your experience

896.19.text: that you get to the finished product.

899.11.text:
GRAEME : Favorite subject matter,
I know it's the big animals, but which animal?

903.31.text: KATE : I do love the cats.

905.36.text: I think they are just nature’s ultimate design.

908.16.text:
And I guess it's sometimes,
it’s that domestic cat familiarity with them,

912.62.text: but you know, when I look at her,

916.55.text: she's sort of assessing me as well.

918.71.text: And I think, what is she thinking?

920.78.text: She can look docile and quiet;

923.34.text:
in a second it can change.
GRAEME : Yeah absolutely.

925.88.text: KATE : And actually when I was in Tanzania

927.88.text: and we were watching a massive herd of buffalo

933.45.text:
and we were standing up
in the vehicle photographing.

936.69.text: And it was this beautiful quiet scene,

939.56.text:
very serene. I’m thinking ‘oh, look at that
buffalo in the water, that looks fantastic’,

943.52.text: and then the fellow next to me said,

945.84.text:
'oh have a look at that lame buffalo
trailing in the back'.

949.00.text:
And he said, ‘I wonder
how long he's going to last’.

951.97.text: And that word no sooner came out of his mouth,

956.81.text: out of the grass and just leapt on its back.

960.36.text:
The whole scene changed.
All the buffalo spun around to chase her away,

964.17.text: because the one she attacked just bellowed.

966.75.text: And there was dust and birds flew up and...

971.17.text:
and the next minute it was chaos.
GRAEME : Was chaos and carnage.

974.77.text:
GRAEME : At this stage now when you've really
mapped in a lot of what you needed to do.

979.59.text:
Is this where now you start to drop it back a
little bit further and then play with the light?

988.92.text: At this stage it's still fairly flat.

992.34.text:
The eyes are a bit more established,
and the mouth.

994.77.text: I've got my main dark areas in,

998.16.text: and I will now start working on the shadow.

1001.42.text:
GRAEME : Okay.
KATE : This particular reference,

1003.91.text:
she was in the shade under the tree,
so there's not a huge amount of contrast.

1009.09.text: So yes, I'll push in a few more darks now,

1013.09.text:
and get her to sort of start looking
a bit more three dimensional.

1018.36.text: GRAEME : So in looking at your reference photo,

1020.71.text:
you've obviously got a lot of the straw
and the sticks coming up as well.

1024.62.text:
KATE : Yes.
GRAEME : Is that something you put on

1027.09.text: and you take out with that gum rubber later on?

1030.64.text:
GRAEME : And you just sort of
slowly pull it out do you?

1032.92.text:
KATE : Yes I sort of,
because I've laid it down in 2B,

1037.09.text:
I've put a little indication here.
GRAEME : Okay.

1039.53.text:
KATE : I probably won't put
as much grass in there but,

1042.93.text:
just enough as a bit of an interest…
GRAEME : Yeah.

1044.84.text: KATE : …to put her in an environment.

1046.25.text:
GRAEME : Even the subtleties of…
just in here.

1049.47.text:
These little whiskers just down the bottom.
I think it's beautiful.

1053.70.text: I sort of cut in just so a few there,

1057.05.text: and the others will be a bit softer.

1060.43.text: So as far as your artistic formal education,

1063.07.text: I mean mostly self-taught but were there...

1065.47.text: were there any people that came into your life

1070.78.text:
KATE : Yes, well I think my main first
influence was my dad just giving me,

1076.05.text:
you know, profound critiques of work and knowledge
and understanding of nature.

1081.56.text: I think that was really important.

1083.38.text:
I was self-taught right through
until I began painting.

1087.36.text:
And then I took two workshops
in the United States on wildlife,

1093.70.text:
and then I've done three or four over here
on landscapes in oil.

1099.56.text:
So I definitely had to learn to paint,
that just didn't come naturally.

1103.23.text:
GRAEME : It's a tough one isn't it?
KATE : It is yeah.

1105.22.text:
GRAEME : The different subtleties
between the mediums.

1107.97.text:
GRAEME : One doesn’t operate
the same as the other one at all.

1110.23.text:
KATE : No.
GRAEME : In fact they’re poles apart sometimes.

1112.90.text:
KATE : That's right. And it was such a change
from using a fine little pencil point

1117.24.text: and going to a big brush.

1118.67.text: And I tended to use tiny little brushes,

1121.67.text: which wasn't giving me the effect I was after.

1125.61.text:
GRAEME : Alright well as you can see we are
moving along very nicely at the moment.

1129.45.text: I think Kate's at the place within the drawing

1133.17.text:
where she's really starting
to refine certain areas

1136.69.text:
and then really working on those lights
and shades as well.

1142.63.text: Sort of you know, popping out certain areas.

1144.59.text: KATE : Yes, that's pretty much it.

1146.44.text:
GRAEME : It suddenly appears in slow,
subtle blocks all the way through.

1153.16.text: KATE : It's very, very slow and painstaking,

1155.52.text: but I think it gives it the good result…

1160.12.text:
GRAEME : Amazing when you look
at the photo or look at the subject,

1164.06.text:
that there are so many tiny little things that
you tend to miss when you're drawing it.

1170.17.text:
GRAEME : You literally,
you can see into every little…

1172.56.text:
It's sort of like looking into
square centimeter by square centimeter,

1176.07.text:
and then going, 'oh look there's
something else I just didn't notice there.

1179.21.text:
KATE : I think that's the beauty
of drawing slowly like this.

1183.87.text:
It's almost hair-by-hair
and just all those beautiful,

1187.19.text:
beautiful little things in her face
that only nature can design.

1193.55.text:
KATE : Okay, I'm at the stage now
where I might put in some grass.

1198.27.text: And I have with my pencils a sharper one

1202.15.text: and I always keep a blunt one in the same grade.

1205.29.text:
That's a blunt 2B,
which is handy for doing this softer work.

1211.33.text:
So I'll just put in a few
of the strands of grass here.

1215.82.text: GRAEME : So you just put them darkly at first?

1219.07.text:
GRAEME : It gives you a line.
Oh okay, the ones in the back…

1221.60.text:
KATE : Some are a bit darker than others
and then with the knead-able eraser,

1225.25.text: if I get a nice sharp edge on it,

1228.58.text:
and I can just lift out a little bit
of the graphite like that.

1232.77.text:
GRAEME : Would you highlight
those on top of each other?

1235.57.text:
KATE : I will yes and I'll come in with darks
in behind them and it will pop out.

1240.70.text: And then just put her in a bit of an environment

1246.41.text: as well so that will stand out.

1248.72.text:
GRAEME : Alright I might let you work
on that for a little while.

1265.17.text: GRAEME : Well we went to Africa today.

1267.23.text:
Sensational Kate, it was just amazing,
thank you very much.

1270.11.text:
KATE : Thank you.
GRAEME : Kate Ferguson, artist extraordinaire.

1273.15.text:
That was tremendous and your feeling for
wildlife and nature is quite spectacular.

1278.58.text: And as I said we found a kindred spirit

1281.11.text:
when we sat down
on all the things we've done together.

1283.35.text:
KATE : Yes we did.
GRAEME : Which was really great.

1285.18.text:
Now you’re obviously in
a lot of galleries overseas,

1287.43.text: but you’re in a local gallery here as well?

1290.52.text:
KATE : Yes I am.
GRAEME : That is?

1292.25.text: KATE : The Old Post Office Gallery in Seymour.

1294.86.text:
GRAEME : Okay.
So if you want to see some of Kate's work,

1297.93.text:
and you're obviously in the Benalla,
Victoria area, you can pop in there.

1301.32.text:
We hope to get some of your work
in our website as well.

1305.62.text:
GRAEME : We'll put some up
if you would like to come and see it there.

1307.91.text:
I think another thing is important with your
ability as a creator but as a teacher as well,

1314.32.text: you obviously do workshops and teaching.

1317.39.text:
GRAEME : So if somebody
wants too get in touch with you,

1318.75.text: with your website where do they go to?

1324.70.text:
GRAEME : Alright write it down guys,
particularly if you're in the Victoria area.

1327.46.text: And as I said, come to colourinyourlife.com.au

1331.30.text: if you want to see some more of Kate's work.

1333.51.text:
But just a tremendous day,
wonderful atmosphere on your property down here

1338.27.text: and this is a magnificent studio.

1339.77.text: But all I can say is keep doing what you're doing,

1341.91.text:
because it really does
benefit so many other people,

1346.20.text:
But obviously the fact that
you work with these institutions

1349.27.text:
that help all of these animals
throughout the world.

1351.96.text:
And they need as much help
as they can possibly get I can assure you.

1355.15.text: GRAEME : But we're going to head off again.

1356.52.text:
As we always say guys, remember,
make sure you Put Some Colour In Your Life.

1360.20.text:
We'll see you next time. Bye.
KATE : Bye.
